title.narrative: World Vision CORE Project fas II
World Vision CORE Project phase II

description.narrative: Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Projektet syftar till att öka möjligheten för produktiv sysselsättning utanför jordbruket, för ökad inkomst för kvinnor och unga i distrikten Nyamasheke och Rusizi. Detta genom att öka företagande och affärsverksamhet utanför jordbruket för målgruppen, genom förbättrat företagsklimat, ökad tillgång till finansiella tjänster samt informations- och kommunikationsteknologi. Särskilt fokus kommer att läggas på utveckling och av värdekedjor inom honungsproduktion och sömnad för att göra dem mer inkluderande av målgruppen.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The project aims to contribute to productive off-farm employment in order to increase household income for women and youth in Nyamasheke and Rusizi districts. The project contributes to increased off-farm entrepreneurship and market oriented businesses for the target group, through enhanced enabling environment for cooperatives and businesses, increased access to financial services and information and communication technologies. Special focus will be placed on developing the value chains in honey production and tailoring to make them more inclusive of for target group.

tag.narrative: 1.4 - By 2030, ensure that all men and women, in particular the poor and the vulnerable, have equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to basic services, ownership and control over land and other forms of property, inheritance, natural resources, appropriate new technology and financial services, including microfinance.

1.4 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla män och kvinnor, i synnerhet de fattiga och de utsatta, har lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, tillgång till grundläggande tjänster, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till arv, naturresurser, lämplig ny teknik och finansiella tjänster, inklusive mikrokrediter.
5.b - Enhance the use of enabling technology, in particular information and communications technology, to promote the empowerment of women.
5.b - Öka användningen av gynnsam teknik, i synnerhet informations- och kommunikationsteknik, för att främja kvinnors egenmakt
8.5 - By 2030, achieve full and productive employment and decent work for all women and men, including for young people and persons with disabilities, and equal pay for work of equal value.

8.5 - Senast 2030 uppnå full och produktiv sysselsättning med anständiga arbetsvillkor för alla kvinnor och män, inklusive ungdomar och personer med funktionsnedsättning, samt lika lön för likvärdigt arbete.

title.narrative: WORLD VISION CORE PROJECT PHASE II
World Vision CORE Project phase II

description.narrative: Examples of results/outputs under each outcome based on the annual narrative report. OUTCOME 1: Increased off-farm entrepreneurship and market-oriented businesses among women & youth As indicated in the Graph above, VSLAs had over USD 1.1 million in savings as compared to USD 857,000 provided out in loans. WV report that this is indicating that members are servicing their loans well as well as continue to lending to their fellow members, thus a multiplier effect reflected as well as sustainability of the model guaranteed. However, the loans given out in the last half of FY 20 decreased due to the effects of COVID19 pandemic. Although savings were maintained, loans requested were low compared the previous year of implementation. COVID19 Rescue Plan WV reports that the interruption of economic activities country-wide and in project operational areas in particular has affected project beneficiaries in a number of ways including the burden of food insecurity among other vulnerabilities. The restrictions of movement, transport, and market operations have negatively impacted small businesses especially the ones engaged in cross-border businesses. The impact for vulnerable households range from loss of food security and nutritional issues to job and income losses and heightened probability of falling into poverty or chronic poverty. WV reports having supported 6,954 project beneficiaries; 3894 (56%) from Nyamasheke and 3060 (44%) from Rusizi whose businesses were most affected by COVID- 19 with working capital of about USD 52 to be able to revamp their businesses and to be able to provide for their families. WV states that reports show that 49% of the cash received by project beneficiaries during COVID-19 crisis was invested to resume/re-enforce their existing but struggling businesses which are the main sources of household incomes for their survival. About 27% of cash transferred to beneficiaries were able to pay their VSLA loans and resumed their businesses, and 19% more the ones doing cross border trade bought product assets for future resale to reinvest in their businesses once border resume full operations, and 5% opened new ventures and used half of the funds received to spend on immediate needs including food for survival purposes. Although the pandemic has far reaching negative impact on incomes sources of women and youth, these cash transfers have served as a boost for reopening small scale businesses and slowly resume normal operations. This enabled them to provide for their families especially during time COVID19 crisis. The project also constructed 10 hand washing stations at market places in both Rusizi and Nyamasheke districts. In Nyamasheke district, the 5 constructed facilities will mitigate the risk of COVID-19 of the 27,500 people that go this market every week. For Rusizi district, the 5 hand washing stations facilitate 15,555 people to easily access the markets. OUTCOME 2: Improved business competitiveness for Tailoring and Honey value chains through the Market Systems Approach. WV conducted a market system diagnosis to analyze whether the two selected value chains (Honey and tailoring) are still relevant and suitable to improve the livelihoods of women and youth of Ubudehe Categories I & II. During FY 19/20, the project identified and selected the two honey and one tailoring lead firms (LF) to facilitate Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) managed by women and/or youth in Nyamasheke and Rusizi districts to address identified honey and tailoring value chains constraints and provide commercially viable market based solutions. Two honey companies namely ABDC Ltd and The Apiary PTE Ltd and one (1) tailoring company called Ineza Textile Industry Ltd were selected and signed partnership agreements with WVR as LFs effective September 2020. Out of 789 members identified to be involved in honey value chain, 50 % are women and youth (women 40%, youth 10%) and 50% are men. Although the main target groups for the project are women and youth from Category 1& 2 of Ubudehe, due to Rwanda social norms, culture and mindset of rural community members, beekeeping activity in Rwanda was generally reserved for old men and it was like a taboo for women and youth to be involved in this sector. 15 out of 562 members from tailoring groups enrolled in MSA, 88 % are women and youth (women: 50% and youth: 38%). Unlike honey value chain dominated by men, tailoring on another hand is way above dominated by direct project target groups with the intention of empowering women and youth to benefit more from this value especially capitalizing on made in Rwanda program in tailoring and the banning of second hand clothes and improve their incomes as opposed to being the majority participants in the sector without better and reliable income from the value chain. During FY 19/20, the price of collected honey has increased from 2,650 Rwf/kg (Season 2019) to 3,300 Rwf/kg (Season A 2020) equivalent to 24.5% as reported price increase as reported by ABDC Ltd, one of CORE project LF partner to quality improvement (ABDC Ltd, September 2020 monthly report). Also as reported by the same LF partner, ABDC Ltd, the total volume of collected honey has increased from 850 kg (2019 season) to 1,200 kg equivalent to 44.1% increase (ABDC Ltd September 2020 monthly report).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 Big Results Now in Education, Program for Results
COVID-19 Big Results Now in Education, Program for Results

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Big Results Now (BRN) initiativet startades 2013 av Tanzanias regering som ett sätt att snabba på resultat inom flera kritiska områden genom laboratorium som identifierade hur man kan övervinna flaskhalsar och en ny resultatstyrningsmodell. Utifrån Tanzanias egna priortieringar inom utbildningssektorn utformades BRNEd till vilket knöts ett nytt resultatbaserat stöd ”Program for Results” där utbetalningarna kopplades till verifierade resultat i ett programdokument (i form av WBs Project Appraisal Document) som nu ligger till grund för hela programmet. De tre givarna (UK, Sverige och WB) använder samma programdokument som ett gemensamt underlag. I programdokumentet finns bakgrund, analys, förändringsteori, prioriteringar samt de resultat som styr programmet och dess mot prestation kopplade utbetalningar. För att hantera programmet operativt uppdateras kontinuerligt en Program Operation Manual (POM) som ger stöd i genomförandet och uppföljningen.
BRNEd Program for Results startade 2014 och Sverige samt UK anslöt 2015. En gemensam halvtidsöversyn genomfördes hösten 2016 efter två års implementering. Sammanfattningsvis är erfarenheterna positiva. Goda resultat har uppnåtts: två av fyra programmålsindikatorerna hade redan 2016 uppnått slutresultatet för 2018 (läskunnighet och matematik i ÅK 2). I övrigt har 14 av 16 indikatorer uppnåtts eller var på god väg att uppnås (se Conclusion on Performance 2016). Halvtidsöversynen bekräftade också att ägarskapet för den resultatbaserade ansatsen ökat, regeringen har fått en insikt om att programmet är ett användbart instrument för att sätta prioriteringar och via incitament skapa drivkrafter inom förvaltningen att uppnå dem. Ministerierna har tillföljd själva drivit på införandet av nya resultatindikatorer som ersätter redan genomförda aktiviteter trots att det höjer svårighetsgraden.
Vid halvtidsöversynen 2016 framkom även att harmonisering och koordineringen av den nya resultatbaserade modaliteten har stärkts. De barnsjukdomar som fanns såsom osäkerhet kring roller och ansvar, inklusive skillnader i förståelse av modaliteten hos parterna har undan för undan ersatts av en gemensam bild och konkreta åtgärder för att hantera identifierade svagheter och stärka uppföljningen. T ex har det förtydligats att all verifikation av rapporterade resultat ska ske genom extern verifikation av en tredje part och inte delas mellan olika aktörer. En annan barnsjukdom var att kommunnivån inte tillräckligt väl förstod hur de kunde agera för att nå resultat och belönas - något som ändrats genom såväl kommunikationsinsatser som genom att de faktiskt sett att de belönas för resultat. Kommunerna tar nu i ökande grad egna initiativ för att åstadkomma bättre resultat.
Den nya fria grundskolan som infördes efter regeringsskiftet 2015 innebär att informella avgifter eliminerats samt att även högstadiet nu är avgiftsfritt. Inskrivningarna till grundskolan har därmed ökat kraftigt (med cirka en halvmiljon barn - drygt 40%), vilket medfört en akut brist på bland annat infrastruktur och lärare. För att de nyinskrivna barnen, oftast från de fattigaste och mest marginaliserade familjerna, också ska förvärva kunskaper kommer såväl ökade resurser som ökad effektivitet inom utbildningsväsendet vara nödvändig. Utmaningen för sektorn, nu när den negativta trenden har brutits, är att fortsatt förbättra resultaten trots ett ständigt och snabbt ökande elevunderlag.
Efter halvtidsöversynen efterfrågade Tanzania utökat och förlängt stöd till programmet mot bakgrund av de goda resultat som uppnåtts och de utmaningar som bland annat införandet av en avgiftsfri grundskola från och med läsåret 2016 innebär. Tanzanias regering tillsammans med de tre samarbetspartnerna Världsbanken, Storbritannien och Sverige har därefter gemensamt utarbetat ett uppdaterat programförslag under det nya namnet "Education Program for Results (EPforR)" med utbetalningar, baserade på resultatuppfyllelse, under åren 2017-2020. EPforR kan inte möta hela sektorns behov, men förväntas spela en viktig roll såväl finansiellt som tekniskt för att de resultat, som uppnåtts under BRNEd i termer av förbättrade examensresultat, ökad läsförmåga och jämnare fördelning av lärarresurser samt skolpeng, ska kunna upprätthållas och förbättras.
Det uppdaterade programmet har justerats för att öka i relevans, anta nya utmaningar och inkorporera lärdomar.
Följande till utbetalningar kopplade resultat (DLRs) är OFÖRÄNDRADE 2017-2020: DLR 2.1 – Andel utbetalat av prioriterade budgetposter såsom skolpeng och textböcker DLR 2.2 – Andel skolpeng som nått fram till skolorna DLR 3.1 – Publicering av årlig nationell skolstatistik DLR 3.2 – Publicering av lokal skoldata DLR 4.1 – Andel kommuner som uppnått jämnare lärarfördelning DLR 4.2 – Andel skolor som uppnått jämnare lärarfördelning DLR 5.2 – Andel av de skolor med störst förbättring i examensresultat som fått skolpris DLR 6.2 – Ökad läsförståelse i årskurs två
Enbart resultatet kring genomförandet av STEP-programmet (Student Teacher Enrichment Program) har TAGITS BORT då aktiviteten genomförts (DLR 5.3).
NYA DLRs - Grundläggande åtgärder (Foundational Activities) som genomförs 2017 är: DLR 1.1 – Manual för skolinspektion och publicering av kvalitetsbedömningar på skolnivå; DLR 1.2 – Strategi för jämnare fördelning av lärarresurser DLR 1.3 - Strategi för skolbarn med särskilda behov DLR 1.4 - Strategi för skolbyggnation
NYA DLRs som mäts årligen 2017-2020: DLR 2.3 – Textböcker distribuerade till skolorna DLR 6.3 – Ökade kunskaper i matematik i årskurs 2 DLR 7.1 – Andel elever som slutför hela primär- respektive grundskolan (Survival Rate) DLR 7.2 – Andel flickor som fortsätter till högstadiet (sekundärskolan) DLR 8.1 – Andel skolor som publicerar sina kvalitetsbedömningar efter skolinspektion DLR 8.2 – Andel skolor som uppvisar förbättrade resultat i skolinspektionens kvalitetsbedömningar
Utökningen av DLRs ligger i linje med landets prioriteringar inom den nya sektorplanen och innebär en förskjutning utåt i resultatkedjan med indikatorer som i högre grad mäter kvalitet än tidigare – t ex genom att även matematikkunskaper görs till föremål för en DLR (6.2) och att elevernas fulla skolgång följs upp (DLR 7.1). Det senare är särskilt viktigt för att skapa incitament för åtgärder som motverkar avhopp – inte minst med tanke på att många av de nyligen inskrivna eleverna kommer från utsatta förhållanden.
Svenska prioriterade områden har också fått ökat fokus i det uppdaterade programmet. Jämställdhet och flickors rättigheter lyfts fram genom gender uppdelad statistik i resultatuppföljningsramverket samt det nya resultatet avseende flickors möjligheter att läsa vidare på högstadiet (DLR 7.2). Även utsatta barn med särskilda behov inkluderas tydligare genom att en strategi tas fram för dem (DLR 1.3).
Ett förnyat angreppsätt till skolinspektion, med ökat lokalt inflytande och stöd till rektorer och lärare utgör en vital del som Tanzania prioriterar (DLR 1.1, 8.1 och 8.2). Stödet ska även genom DLR 1.2 skapa ökade förutsättningar för jämnare fördelning av lärare då en sådan policy saknats och därmed öka möjligheterna att nå resultat på DLR 4.1 och 4.2. Infrastrukturen som kraftigt behöver expandera för att möta efterfrågan på utbildning förutsätter att ett kostnadseffektivt angreppssätt utformas och följs för att vara uthållig (DLR 1.4). Produktionen av skolböcker dras med problem som behöver lösas ut centralt, men den nya DLR 2.3 ger incitament att få ut läroböcker till skolorna och hanterar effektivt risken för svinn genom att enbart böcker som når skolorna kommer ge utbetalning.
Sammantaget stärks med dessa förändringar insatsens fattigdomsfokus, flickors rättigheter adresseras mer direkt och risker som identifierats hanteras via nya resultat.
ADMINISTRATIVA ÖVERVÄGANDEN
I enlighet med insatshanteringsregeln, § 3.11.3, och processen för kompletterande beslut har den tidigare beredningen gåtts igenom med ett fokus på att säkerställa att resultat- och riskregistret samt riskhanteringen är baserade på uppdaterade bedömningar och dokumenterade lärdomar. Nya förhållanden har beaktats och beredningen har uppdaterats avseende väsentliga förändringar vilka tydligt markerats.
Det nya avtalet ersätter i ljuset av de påkallade justeringarna det tidigare avtalet för att skapa tydlighet. Samtliga tidigare rapporteringskrav som fortfarande är aktuella, t ex revisionerna för 2015/16 har integrerats i det uppdaterade avtalet. Ett nytt uppdaterat programdokumentet (bilaga 1 till avtalet) utgör basen tillsammans med tabellen (bilaga 2) som anger maximalt värde för de specifika resultat Sverige avser belöna 2017-2020. Avtalet anger även som villkor att programmets operativa manual uppdateras och reflekterar alla förändringar av programmet till och med 2019/20 vad gäller resultatramverk och prestationer kopplade till utbetalningar i enlighet med avtalets bilaga 2. Det nya avtalet inkluderar även, utöver de nya medel om 755 MSEK som detta beslut avser, kvarvarande (ännu inte utbetalda) medel för åren 2017-18 om 130 MSEK från original beslutets total om 300 MSEK för "BRNEd Program for Results". Det nya avtalet summerar därför till 885 MSEK. Utanför såväl det nya som tidigare avtalet, finns även en till insatsen tillhörande komponent om 10 MSEK för svensk kontraktering av uppföljning/studier mm (se beslut 2015-06-30, 15007579).

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 After the mid-term review of the performance based program "Big Results Now in Education, Program for Results" (BRNEd PforR) 2014-2018 Tanzania requested development partners to expand and extend the support to the program in the light of the initial good results and the challenges ahead in implementing the free basic school policy introduced in the academic year of 2016. The Tanzanian government together with three partners; the World Bank, the UK and Sweden, have jointly prepared an updated program under the new name "Education Program for Results (EPforR)", with payments dependent on the degree of results achievements, during the years 2017-2020.
The introduction of the free basic education means that informal fees are being eliminated and that lower secondary school is now free of charge. Enrollments to primary school has as a consequence increased sharply in 2016 (by about half a million children - more than 40%), which have resulted in an acute shortage of infrastructure, learning materials and teachers. To uphold the recent gains in quality of education, while also catering for learning needs of these new groups of pupils that often come from poor and marginalized families, is a formidable challenge that will require increased resources, as well as, improved efficiency. Otherwise, there is a high risk that the achievements made in recent years cannot be maintained and that the quality of education deteriorates again.
EPforR is expected to play an important role both financially and technically to sustain and improve further the results achieved during BRNEd in terms of improved exam results, increased reading skills, better statistics and more equitable distribution of teachers and resources including capitation grants. The expanded contribution builds on the lessons learned over the first two years of implementation and retains the same development objective: to improve the quality of education in Tanzanian primary and secondary schools.
Support for delivering results on the basis of the key reforms that were initiated during BRNEd continues incentivizing that: capitation grants arrives in time to the schools; teacher are motivated; even distribution of teacher resources, transparency and publishing of school statistics, schools that improve are rewarded, and increasing skills in reading, writing and arithmetic (3R) already at early ages.
Support for already completed activities cease, and are being replaced with incentives for: a quality assurance system with its school inspection and publication of quality assessments at a school level in order to raise the general level of quality; girls' education and opportunities to continue to high school (secondary school); access to textbooks; and incentives for completing school and prevent drop-outs. In other words, the poverty focus will be further strengthened and girls' rights will be addressed more directly.
The experience of the new result-based modality is also generally positive. The set-up problems that existed, including differences in the understanding of the modality of the partners, have gradually been replaced by a common understanding and concrete action to address identified weaknesses and to strengthen monitoring. The ownership of the program is strong, and Tanzania sees the program as an instrument for setting priorities and incentives. Subsequently, the ministries have pushed for the introduction of new results, replacing already implemented activities, even though it raises the bar for payment.
External verification of the results has contributed to the credibility, and lessons learned have been incorporated into the program operation manual that have been continuously updated. However, there is a need for further simplification and a risk management that is better adapted to realities and capacities. In light of these experience and the lessons that have been documented in Sida's new method guidance (Dec 2016) for results-based approaches, the risk assessment and management have been revised, which is also reflected in the attached draft agreement.
The former appraisal have been examined in accordance to the contribution management rule, § 3.11.3, and the process for supplementary decisions. The results- and risk register have been revised, and adjustments have been made in terms of risk management based on an updated assessments of risk and lessons learned. Other assessments in the appraisal, apart form the budget section, have in line with the recommendation by the quality assurance committee not been updated - new conditions have, however, been included in the overall assessment of the operation below.
In order to simplify and have a clear understanding the original agreement will be replaced by a new agreement. All reporting conditions that are still valid, e.g. the audits of FY 15/16, have been incorporated into the updated agreement. The new updated program document forms the basis for the contribution and is annexed to the new agreement together with an annex showing the Disbursement Linked Results and their maximum value 2017-2020. A key agreement condition is that the program operation manual is updated to reflect the new program up to the year 2019/20 in terms of results framework and Disbursement Linked Results. The new agreement also includes undisbursed funds of 130 MSEK for 2017-18 from the original decision's 300 MSEK for the BRNEd Program for Results in addition to the new 755 MSEK. The new agreement thus cover in total 885 MSEK for the 4-year period 2017-2020. The original decision also added a component of 10 MSEK for monitoring and evaluation that lies outside the original as well as the new agreement.

The overall objective is to improve education quality at primary and lower secondary level. The Education Program for Results (EPforR) is a multi-donor project funded by the UK Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO), the World Bank (WB), the Swedish Government (Sida), the Korean Government (KOICA) and the Global Partnership for Education (GPE), using a ‘programming for results’ modality to bring about meaningful change in the basic education sector in Tanzania. The programme has run since 2014 and is ending this year (2021). This modality - the performance based financing mechanism - sets out release of funds once the agreed Disbursed Linked Results (DLRs) are achieved in accordance with the Program Operational Manual and a Verification Report submitted by a Technical Assitance Support Team (TAS). These DLRs initially covered six areas: (1) foundational activities, setting up the underlying systems necessary for the other DLRs; (2) adequate and timely resource flows; (3) improved information system; (4) more equitable teacher deployment; (5) implementation of selected priority initiatives; and (6) educational outcomes. With the approval of the Additional Financing in 2017, three more areas were added: (7) improved student retention; (8) effective schools quality assurance system; and (9) education policy making capacity built. The Swedish Embassy assesses that the programme continues to be highly effective, and overall performance in Year 6 has improved on the previous two years.

participating-org.narrative: Performance for Big Results/Ministry of Finance/The United Republic of Tanzania

tag.narrative: 4.1 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes.
4.1 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar fullbordar avgiftsfri och likvärdig grundskole- och gymnasieutbildning av god kvalitet som leder till relevanta och ändamålsenliga kunskaper.
4.2 - By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education.
4.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla flickor och pojkar har tillgång till förskola av god kvalitet som ger omvårdnad och förbereder dem för att börja grundskolan.

Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: The performance in this 6th year is perhaps the most exceptional in the lifespan of the programme, posting an overall 11.3% improvement since last year. Four out of the 14 Disbursement-Linked Results (DRLs) disbursed this year has improved in performance, despite the second half of the year being affected by the Covid 19 pandemic. Improvement in results can be contributed to governments commitment to this programme. Main improvements cover student retention, effective school quality assurance system as well as adequate and timely resource management and improved information system. The DLRs that improved performance are “foundational activities, setting up the underlying systems necessary for the other DLRs” with 60 % improvement, “improved student retention” improved with 28 % and “adequate and timely resource flows” with 4 %. Being outcome indicators, the exemplary performance in these indicators indicate that the programme has been successful in contributing to improved learning in Tanzania. The programme has also improved the learning for girls. This year, the indicator on girls’ transition continued to perform very well. Only three Regions (Geita, Kigoma and Mara) had a GPI of girls transition of less than 90%. In general therefore, the performance against most DLRs is viewed by the Embassy as above satisfactory-level.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAP) i Tanzania är designat för att stärka FN-systemets samstämmighet och effektivitet på nationell nivå, som bidrag till Tanzanias arbete för hållbar fattigdomsminskning och förverkligandet av mänskliga rättigheter. Den breda verksamheten motsvarar flera av de mål som anges i den svenska resultatstrategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med Tanzania 2013-2019. Fyra av totalt tolv resultatområden är särskilt relevanta för den svenska strategin: god samhällstyrning/mänskliga rättigheter/gender; våld mot kvinnor och barn; kvinnligt deltagande och politiskt ledarskp; samt ekonomisk tillväxt och sysselsättning. Den svenska strategin identifierar kvinnor, barn och ungdomar som prioriterade målgrupper vilket också reflekteras väl i de områden för stöd som Sida valt.
UNDAP II är helt i linje med givarnas s k Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) och med Tanzanias nationella visioner (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II är också utvecklad i linje med Tanzanias femårsplan 2015/16 - 2020/21 och med de globala hållbarhets- och utvecklingsmålen. Programmet bidrar till FN:s fokus på förbättrade resultat och samstämmighet genom att sammanföra ett 20-tal FN-organs planering, budgetering och rapportering i ett gemensamt resultatramverk för Tanzania. UNDAP II minskar därför i viss utsträckning även dubbelarbete för nationella partner såväl som för FN organisationer.
Det svenska stödet ska ges via One UN Fund, i linje med Sveriges politik att stödja ett sammanhållet och mer effektivt FN-arbete i länderna (FN-reformen "Delivering as One", DaO). UNDP är det av FN utsedda FN-organ som administrerar One UN Fund (genom UNDP-kontoret i Dar es Salaam och huvudkontoret i New York), och UN Resident Coordinator (UNRC) FN:s högste representant i Tanzania, varför båda dessa står som FN:s undertecknande av SAA med Sida. I linje med Sveriges resultatstrategi för Tanzania kommer stödet inte att gå generellt till UNDAP, utan som öronmärkt till de fyra nämnda resultatområdena.
Medlen kommer att fördelas enligt nedan till följande resultatområden: - Ekonomisk tillväxt och anställning: 125 000 000 SEK - God samhällsstyrning och mänskliga rättigheter: 82 500 000 SEK - Kvinnors politiska deltagande: 50 000 000 SEK - Våld mot kvinnor och barn: 42 500 000 SEK

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAP) in Tanzania is designed to strengthen the co-ordination and effectiveness of the UN system at national level, as a contribution to Tanzania's efforts to achieve sustainable poverty reduction and the implementation of human rights. The broad business corresponds to several of the goals set out in the Swedish Development Cooperation Development Strategy Tanzania 2013-2019. Four out of twelve results areas are particularly relevant to the Swedish strategy: good governance / human rights / gender; violence against women and children; female participation and political leadership; as well as economic growth and employment. The Swedish strategy identifies women, children and adolescents as prioritized target groups, which also reflects well in the areas of support chosen by Sida.
UNDAP II is fully in line with the donors' Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) and with Tanzania's National Visions (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II is also developed in line with Tanzania's five-year plan 2015/16 - 2020/21 and with global sustainability and development goals. The program contributes to the UN's focus on improved results and coherence by bringing together 20 UN agencies' planning, budgeting and reporting in a joint performance framework for Tanzania. UNDAP II therefore, to a certain extent, also reduces duplication for national partners as well as UN organizations.
Swedish support will be provided through One UN Fund, in line with Sweden's policy to support a coherent and more effective UN work in the countries (UN reform "Delivering as One", DaO). UNDP is the UN-designated UN body that manages the One UN Fund (through the UNDP office in Dar es Salaam and the headquarters in New York), and the UN Resident Coordinator (UNRC) UN High Representative in Tanzania, why both of them stand as UN signing of SAA with Sida. In line with Sweden's earnings strategy for Tanzania, the support will not go to UNDAP generally, but as earmarked for the four mentioned results areas.
The funds will be distributed as follows to the following results areas: - Economic growth and employment: SEK 125,000,000 - Good governance and human rights: 82 500 000 SEK - Women's political participation: SEK 50,000,000 - Violence against women and children: 42 500 000 SEK

description.narrative: Progress towards Outcomes results Economic Growth and Employment The outcome area comprises of 13 UN agencies contributing towards three outputs, see below. The outcome group is currently contributing to two Joint Programmes, one in Kigoma (the Kigoma Joint Programme) and one in Zanzibar (the Zanzibar Joint Programme) The outcome group is coordinated by ILO and have a designated person coordinating monitoring and results reporting. The group have monthly meetings where the different UN agencies are present. This is an opportunity for the UN agencies to share lessons learnt and exchange ideas and find synergies between themselves. In March 2019 the outcome group had a joint retreat focusing on the MSD approach to learn from each other and deepen the understanding of the concept. The EoS is present in the outcome meetings and it gives a good opportunity to get an insights of the work of the outcome group. The delivery rate for the outcome Economic Growth and employment for the period 2018-2019 is 83% of annual targets fully or close to fully achieved. Output 1 Relevant MDAs and selected LGAs have strengthened capacities to review and implement evidence based economic policies and plans to be business enabling, environmentally sustainable and gender responsive: In Zanzibar, technical and financial assistance contributed to the finalisation of the Agriculture Sector Development Programme and the Youth Development Policy. On mainland inputs supported the finalization of the Microfinance Act and Microfinance Regulations. At sub-national level 33 regional and LGAs were enabled to create national plans, budgets and investments that integrated poverty, environmental and gender concerns. Concrete examples are six Regional Investment Guidelines designed to attract local/foreign investments and nine private partnerships resulting in revenue generating facilities. Training in Gender responsive budgeting have provided eight LGAs better equipped to manage district development funds for women and youth, demonstrated by a 26,5% increase in allocations and utilization over the last two years and the figures rised from TZS 592.8 million to 796.5 million. Input on Output 2 Relevant institutions have enhanced capacities to provide gender-responsive, market-oriented, quality programmes, products and services Following UN technical advice and financial support, 74 institutions with national or local reach delivered market-oriented and gender responsive training programmes and business development support products and services. This includes 8 skills development institutions such as the NCT and ZITOD, leading to the successful graduation of the first batch of 52 apprentices from the Zanzibar Quality Apprenticeship Programme in Hotel Operations. Strengthen the capacity of Tanzania Investment Centre to manage e-regulations platforms, which has made it easier for investors and entrepreneurs to start a business Through trainings and technical advice, 11 LGAs and 3 agricultural training institutions have strengthened capacity to provide agri-business development support including on good agronomic practices, climate-smart agriculture, and entrepreneurship. This will contribute to improved access to quality extension advice for women and men farmers and entrepreneurs. Input on Output 3 Micro, small, medium and large enterprises, in particular those led by women and youth, have strengthened capacities to increase productivity, add value to their products and access markets More than 38 000 micro enterprises (both on mainland and Zanzibar) have strengthened capacities to increase productivity, add value to their products and access markets. The assistance from UNDAPII has ranged from providing trainings on GAP and construction of aggregation centres and storage facilities (28, 500 famers have reported a decrease in post-harvest losses from 40% to 27%) to facilitating links between farmers and traders. In Zanzibar, 180 primarily women seaweed farmers were provided with knowledge and skills to embark on sea cucumber farming as a new livelihood opportunity, while training of 40 youth (60% women) on value addition led to improved packaging and increased competitiveness. Access to finance initiatives led to more than 35,220 people (W: 21,504, M: 11,343, Y: 2,373) accessing financial services through savings groups, SACCOS, community banks and commercial banks. Additional 4,170,503 people (55% women) were reached through an IFAD loan. Progress towards Outcomes result Democratic Governance, Human Rights & Gender Equality The outcome area comprises of 4 UN agencies contributing towards three outputs, see below. The outcome group is coordinated by UNDP and it has a designated person who is responsible for coordinating, monitoring and results reporting. The group does meet every now and then, but it is not clear how regularly this occurs and whether all the involved UN agencies are always present. EoS has only been invited to and present at 2 outcome meetings during the period Aug 2018 – Aug 2020, which substantially limits the EoS’ opportunity to get an insight into the work of the outcome group. Minutes from potential meetings where EoS has not been invited have also not been shared. This is a pity since such meetings are an opportunity for the UN agencies to share lessons learnt and exchange ideas and find synergies between themselves, from which the EoS can learn and understand the effectiveness of the outcome group and the work it delivers. Output 1 Citizens of Tanzania especially the most marginalized have increased capacity to engage and participate in policy formulation, implementation and monitoring. During the reporting period, 119 CSOs were supported to engage with parliamentary committees and/or participate in public hearings across a range of issues, including discussions around the Political Parties (Amendment) Bill, the Finance Bill and sectoral budget reviews. The National Assembly was also enabled to better integrate gender equality and women’s empowerment (GEWE) concerns, with support in mainstreaming gender equality in all functions following a gender audit and capacity needs assessment. Follow-up initiatives included the introduction of a HeforShe Advocacy strategy promoting male MP champions for GEWE and the production/dissemination of a handbook on gender mainstreaming and programming. Output 2 The Government of Tanzania has enhanced capacity to comply with International and Regional human rights standards and implement recommendations from human rights mechanisms, including those related to access to justice for women, children and other vulnerable groups. There is a clear recognition that during this period there have been some challenging developments in the country however, despite these developments quite a number of important activities have been advanced under UNDAP II. The UN reports that the Government of Tanzania has increased its capacity to comply with human rights standards during the reporting period, especially in areas related to access to justice for women and children and other vulnerable groups. Legal Aid services were expanded through a range of measures including the roll-out of a MOU between the Ministry of Constitutional and Legal Affairs, Ministry of Home Affairs, Tanzania Police Force and Tanzania Prison Services for improved access by Legal Aid Providers to prisons and other places of detention plus the piloting of a legal aid coordination mechanism which reduced bureaucracy, improved sub-national oversight and provided clear referral pathways. Furthermore, following technical and financial assistance to Tanzania Network of Legal Aid Providers (TANLAP) 127,452 people (84,932 females and 42,550 males) in Kagera region benefitted from legal aid services who would otherwise been left unserved. In addition, access to justice specifically for minors was also improved with UN support. Following trainings of 500+ personnel attached to 130 Juvenile Courts, magistrate adherences to statutes of limitations (adhering to the maximum time after a criminal act within which legal proceeding shall be initiated) was increased and reviews of past cases were undertaken, with fewer children sent to prison as a result. In addition, child protection was integrated into the training curriculum of an estimated 4,500 community-based paralegals and the Zanzibar Kadhi Court Rules were amended to include the best interest of the child and presence of Social Workers during hearings. Further, the Ministry of Health, Community Development, Gender, Elderly and Children (MHCDGEC) signed Community Rehabilitation Programme Guidelines (CRP), formalizing diversion for children in conflict with the law. Rather than focusing on punishment, diversion programmes aim at rehabilitation of the offender and prevention of further offences by seeking to address the underlying factors that contribute to criminal behaviour. Tanzania mainland now has three such CRPs operating independent of UN financial support with six more in development. Output 3 Relevant Governance stakeholders have increased capacities to generate, analyse and use evidence to formulate and implement gender responsive, inclusive policies, strategies and programmes for the most marginalized. With UN support, the Government of Tanzania met their reporting obligations with submissions for the CEDAW Mid Term Review and the Beijing Platform for Action 25+. The Government also presented their 2019 Voluntary National Review (VNR) at the High-Level Political Forum in New York in July 2019. In the lead-up, the MHCDGEC was assisted to engage with the VNR national technical team to produce a Gender Report for the relevant SDGs, thereby ensuring GEWE concerns were strongly represented. The UN also reports that their support has ensured that relevant Governance stakeholders now are more capable of generating, analysing and using evidence to inform policies, strategies and programmes. One important example includes the expansion of the Simplified Birth Registration System (SBRS) for children under five from 11 to 13 regions with approximately 3.6 million now registered and issued with a birth certificate. This is an increase of the overall birth certification rate in the 13 regions from 12.7% (2012) to 42.9% on the mainland and 9.3% (2012) to 80.2% in Zanzibar and represents significant progress under SDG 16.9.1. Another example concerns gender responsive budgeting where relevant stakeholders now have improved their capacity to cost, track and report on public resource allocations following the finalisation of Guidelines to operationalize the Gender and Development Policy (2016) in Zanzibar and the development of a matrix to track resource allocations across MDAs and LGAs developed by the Gender Mainstreaming Working Group-Macro Policy. Progress towards Outcomes results Womens Political Participation and Leadership Interventions under this outcome were intended to increase the number of women who will stand for upcoming elections. During this period some of the key results included: 1. Capacities of 289 key stakeholders (232 women; 57 men) from Mainland and Zanzibar were strengthened on gender gaps in five election related laws through training sessions. 2. Information Lab has been set up to raise awareness on violence against women in politics.The information Laboratory has a role to collect, analyse, disseminate data and raise awareness on VAWP and has been established in collaboration with the University of Dar es Salaam Department of Political Science and the Institute of Gender Studies. A total of 32 women aspirants have been supported by the Information Lab. 3. Capacity of 402 political party leaders (202 women, 200 men) were trained on their role to advance WLPP and hence their capacities strengthened on this area. 4. Three women were appointed to the Ethical Committee by ZEC as a result of policy level advocacy and dialogues with the Zanzibar Electoral Committee. 5. Advocacy through TWPG and WROs undertaken on the inclusion of GEWE principles in the Political Parties (Amendment) Act, 2019. 6. A comprehensive training manual to strengthen capacities of political parties on women’s leadership and political participation was developed. furthermore, a comprehensive Training of trainers manual and workbook for women aspiring for political leadership was adopted. 7. Two political parties’ manifestos have specific provisions indicating commitment to promote WLPP and unofficial data from parliamentary parties indicated an increase of 7% of nominations of women for Parliament positions. 8. In 2019, all the 19 registered political parties adopted a formula to guide the selection of women aspirants for the transformational leadership trainings. 9. A total of 202 women leaders from all registered political parties were trained on their role to promote women’s leadership and participation and committed to influence nominations. 10. An assessment on the strength and weaknesses of women wings in political parties was conducted to identify gaps and provide recommendations for improvement. 11. The Tanzania Chapter of African Women Leaders Network was launched on the 26th of February 2020. Over 200 women and young women leaders in politics, academia, research, civil society, civil service, the private sector, women living in rural areas, and the media are members and participated in the launch. 12. A total of 361 Womens Rights Organisations and networks are implementing various interventions to advance women’s leadership and political participation in Tanzania Mainland and Zanzibar. Progress towards Outcome Ending Violence Against Women and Children 1. The Government became a signatory to the WeProtect Statement of Action, which presents opportunities for Tanzania to access global expertise in formulating policies, legislation and programmes to tackle online exploitation and abuse of children. 2. Increased advocacy for the inclusion of interventions (and budgets) to implement the National Plan of Action to End Violence Against Women and Children in the national planning and budgeting guidelines for 2018/2019 resulted in 8 key Ministries committing USD 2million. 3. Increased efforts to strengthen violence prevention and response services resulted in the renovation of six Mainland and 3 Zanzibar Police and Gender Desks. Training of Police Officers was also done in order to build their capacity to provide a comprehensive, respectful and effective response to violence cases. The Tanzania Police Force was also supported to develop national Guidelines on the Gender Responsive Reporting System, which has been disseminated to police stations nationwide. 4. Development of a mobile phobe application that will be linked to the District case management system ( DCMS) and hence improve case and data management as it will enable Social Welfare Officers to receive information on initial investigation of child protection cases. 5. Strengthened capacity of service providers to ensure accessibility and availability of essential services for women survivors of violence and Social workers in Dodoma and Shinyanga assigned to provide psychosocial support for women traders and vendors in the marketplace. 6. Advocacy efforts resulted in reporting of 2,163 cases of violence against women and girls following activities organised by community and youth activists, community development officers and healthcare workers across six districts. furthermore, a total of 14,245 cases of violnce against women were reported at Police Gender and Children Desks in Mainland and 752 cases reported in Zanzibar. 7. In the education sector, the UN partnership with the Ministry of Education and Presidents Office-Regional and Local Government resulted in training of teachers to provide guidance and counselling services and to assist establishment of TUSEME ( Lets Speak Out) Clubs. 2,227 primary schools were reached in Mbeya, Iringa and Njombe. In Zanzibar, 463 Guidance and Counselling Teachers in 232 schools have been trained and 138,912 students recived messages on the prevention and response to violnce.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 United Nations Development Assistance Plan (UNDAP) i Tanzania är designat för att stärka FN-systemets samstämmighet och effektivitet på nationell nivå, som bidrag till Tanzanias arbete för hållbar fattigdomsminskning och förverkligandet av mänskliga rättigheter. Den breda verksamheten motsvarar flera av de mål som anges i den svenska resultatstrategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med Tanzania 2013-2019. Fyra av totalt tolv resultatområden är särskilt relevanta för den svenska strategin: god samhällstyrning/mänskliga rättigheter/gender; våld mot kvinnor och barn; kvinnligt deltagande och politiskt ledarskp; samt ekonomisk tillväxt och sysselsättning. Den svenska strategin identifierar kvinnor, barn och ungdomar som prioriterade målgrupper vilket också reflekteras väl i de områden för stöd som Sida valt.
UNDAP II är helt i linje med givarnas s k Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) och med Tanzanias nationella visioner (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). UNDAP II är också utvecklad i linje med Tanzanias femårsplan 2015/16 - 2020/21 och med de globala hållbarhets- och utvecklingsmålen. Programmet bidrar till FN:s fokus på förbättrade resultat och samstämmighet genom att sammanföra ett 20-tal FN-organs planering, budgetering och rapportering i ett gemensamt resultatramverk för Tanzania. UNDAP II minskar därför i viss utsträckning även dubbelarbete för nationella partner såväl som för FN organisationer.
Det svenska stödet ska ges via One UN Fund, i linje med Sveriges politik att stödja ett sammanhållet och mer effektivt FN-arbete i länderna (FN-reformen "Delivering as One", DaO). UNDP är det av FN utsedda FN-organ som administrerar One UN Fund (genom UNDP-kontoret i Dar es Salaam och huvudkontoret i New York), och UN Resident Coordinator (UNRC) FN:s högste representant i Tanzania, varför båda dessa står som FN:s undertecknande av SAA med Sida. I linje med Sveriges resultatstrategi för Tanzania kommer stödet inte att gå generellt till UNDAP, utan som öronmärkt till de fyra nämnda resultatområdena.
Medlen kommer att fördelas enligt nedan till följande resultatområden: - Ekonomisk tillväxt och anställning: 125 000 000 SEK - God samhällsstyrning och mänskliga rättigheter: 82 500 000 SEK - Kvinnors politiska deltagande: 50 000 000 SEK - Våld mot kvinnor och barn: 42 500 000 SEK

UNDAP II is fully in line with the donors' Joint Assistance Strategy for Tanzania (JAST) and with Tanzania's National Visions (The Tanzania Development Vision 2025 and Zanzibar Vision 2020). sector.narrative: Public sector policy and administrative management

tag.narrative: 5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

5.a - Genomföra reformer för att ge kvinnor lika rätt till ekonomiska resurser, möjlighet att äga och kontrollera mark och andra former av egendom samt tillgång till finansiella tjänster, arv och naturresurser, i enlighet med nationell lagstiftning

5.a - Undertake reforms to give women equal rights to economic resources, as well as access to ownership and control over land and other forms of property, financial services, inheritance and natural resources, in accordance with national laws.
