description.narrative: The Mid Term Review (MTR) needs to be awaited to follow-up on the results, as the MTR will report against the baseline. Below is a summary of indicative and observed results reported in the progress report for year 1. Component 1, Community-based Socio-therapy, has overall created outcomes on both the individual, family and community level: On the individual level, many members of the CBS reported that their former low tolerance for disagreements and responding to issues in an aggressive and emotional manner has changed, resulting in more constructive ways to solve conflicts in the communities. On the family level, the reported results within and between families are improved relationships among community members and that the role of each family member now is better recognized by each member in the family. In and between target communities, the project has contributed to more interaction, and discussion of development issues of common concern, between community leaders and community members. This has resulted in built and strengthened relationships amongst and between the youth and women groups and the local authorities. The project has resulted in a demonstrated will by the Liberia National Police, women groups, elders, religious and community leaders to participate in the Community Leaders Forum and the Civil Trust Workshops. The participants have demonstrated a commitment by their active participation in the meetings and their engagement in follow up actions. The project has enabled for citizens in some of the project locations (particularly in Yekepa, Sinje and West Point) to have direct access to their lawmakers and hence resulted in citizens using this opportunity actively to raise issues and concerns with them to find common solutions. Furthermore, the project has made the local government officials that are participating in the forums more receptive to the concerns and proactive in the solving of the problems brought to them.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 I FN:s Säkerhetsrådsresolution 2239 från 2015, bekräftades att FN:s fredsbevarande mission i Liberia (UNMIL) som funnits på plats i landet sedan 2003, ska dras tillbaka den 30 september i år. Neddragningen har skett gradvis under de senaste åren och innebär en successiv överlämning av ansvar till den liberianska regeringen (GoL) för säkerheten i landet och skydd av civilbefolkningen. Liberias regering återtog, som resolutionen påbjöd, fullt ansvar för säkerheten i landet den 30 juni i år, men allvarliga resurs- och kapacitetsbrister föreligger. I resolutionen skriver Säkerhetsrådet att Liberias regering bör arbeta fram en plan med tidslinjer och indikatorer för säkerhetssektorreform innehållande planer för ledarskap, koordinering, uppföljning och resurser, översynsmekanismer etcetera. Resolutionen understryker vikten av att GoL genomför reform av säkerhets- respektive rättssektorn.
GoL tog fram Government of Liberia Plan for UNMIL Transition med en narrativ text kring utmaningar och prioriteringar samt en matris med mål och aktiviteter. Transitionsplanen är gravt underfinansierad och understryker behovet av stöd från internationella givare till transitionsplanen och säkerhetssektorn i stort.
Svag kapacitet hos implementerande parter och korruption i säkerhets- och rättsinstitutionerna medför en relativt hög risknivå som fordrar noggrann uppföljning. På grund av neddragningen av UNMIL och det svaga givarstödet till Liberia generallt och till dessa processer specifikt, är behoven stora och absorptionskapaciteten hög.Sverige är en av få givare som dessutom har en välbemannad ambassad i Liberia och har därför möjlighet att följa upp stödet bättre. Sverige är därför en av de viktigaste givarna i denna sektor och har tillsammans med USA ingått i flera arbetsgrupper med GoL för att planera den kommande fredsbyggandestrukturen i landet.
UNDPs/UNMILs Rule of Law Joint Programme har utformats för att stödja GoL i arbetet med att genomföra transitionsplanen samt bygger vidare på målen i planen. Programmet syftar till att säkerställa en sammanhållen strategi för säkerhetssektorreform och ökad rättssäkerhet samt till att stödja implementeringen av dessa reformprocesser. UNDP och UNMIL (under Department for Peacekeeping Operations, DPKO) har utvecklat ett gemensamt program för detta. Programmet fokuserar på kapacitetsuppbyggnad av statliga säkerhets- och rättsinstitutioner samt av civilsamhället; etablering av översynsmekanismer och standardiserade rutiner; förbättrat samarbete bland aktörer i hela rättskedjan; stärkt och adekvat nationellt juridiskt ramverk samt; stärka jämställdhetsperspektiv i hela rättskedjan och öka kvinnors och flickors rättssäkerhet. Detta är tänkt att förbättra tillhandahållandet av säkerhets- och rättsliga tjänster och därmed även bygga förtroende hos befolkningen och förbättra relationen mellan stat och befolkning.
Konceptet med ett gemensamt program (joint programme) innebär en rad aktiviteter som ingår i en gemensam arbetsplan och budgetram, som per definition omfattar två eller fler FN-organisationer och syftar till att uppnå resultat i linje med nationella prioriteringar som återspeglas i United Nations Development Assistance Framework (UNDAF) / One Program. Arbetsordningen och budgetram mellan UNDP och UNMIL utgör en del av programdokumentet, som specificerar roller och ansvar. Programmets koordineras av UNDP och UNMIL i samarbete med GoL, men anlitar även det civila samhällets organisationer som genomförandepartner. Sverige, representerat av Sida, ingår ett avtal med UNDP. Av Sida fastställd avtalsmall "Third Party Cost Sharing Agreement" används (senaste version av mallen fastställd genom Sida beslut 2016-002132).
Samförståndsavtal kommer att ingås mellan UNDP och UNMIL som anger att UNDP ska bära det fulla ansvaret för att genomföra programmet och anta ekonomisk ansvarsskyldighet för de medel som ställs till förfogande. Avtalsmallen har delats med ambassaden men kommer formellt att ingås senare på året. Dock har UNDP, UNMIL och GoL formellt signerat programdokumentet. Programmet kommer att ha full tillgång till de tjänster som tillhandahålls av UNDPs operativa enheter samt följa UNDPs regelverk, men dra nytta av UNMILs operativa fördelar. Enligt UNDPs finansiella regler och förordningar, kommer UNDP förvalta mottagen finansiering; framställa konsoliderade narrativa och ekonomiska rapporter, inklusive certifierade bokslut. UNDP kommer att ta ut en 8% avgift för administrationskostnader, så kallad General Management Services (GMS). UNMIL bidrar med kompetens i enlighet med sitt uppdrag i Liberia och specifikt för sin kompetens som en fredsbyggande mission. UNMILs pågående neddragning och kommande totala tillbakadragande, vars tidpunkt beslutas av säkerhetsrådet i december 2016, innebär att det är möjligt (troligt) att programmet kommer att pågå efter tillbakadragandet av UNMIL. Ambassaden bedömer att UNMILs bidrag i programmet i form av kompetens, resurser och nätverk är en fördel för programmet men som ändå kan övertas av UNDP vid ett totalt tillbakadragande av UNMIL. Detta baseras på tidigare erfarenhet av UNDP i säkerhets- och rättsuppbyggnad i Liberia.
Programmet bygger på UNDPs program Justice and Security Joint Programme (avslutat) och pågående Justice and Security Trust Fund II (JSTF II) som Ambassaden har finansierat, varav den senare med SEK 30 498 948 (insatsnummer 52090042). Aktivitetsperioden för JSTF II har nyligen förlängts utan medelstillägg till 2017-04-31. JSTF II har fokuserat på kapacitetsuppbyggnad av Liberias säkerhet –och rättssektor vilket är en huvudprioritet i Liberias transitionsplan. Implementering av JSTF II fördröjdes kraftigt på grund av ebolautbrottet men måluppfyllelse och resultatrapportering för insatsen har uppfyllt ambassadens krav. Programmet har uppnått flera viktiga resultat gällande att stärka kapaciteten för Liberias övertagande av säkerheten i landet samt att öka rättssäkerheten.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 The UNDP/UNMIL Joint Rule of Law Programme aims at ensuring a more joined-up approach to rule of law, UNDP and UNMIL intend to develop a joint rule of law, justice and security (ROLJS) programme aimed at successfully implementing UNMIL's mandated tasks and facilitating a seamless transition to more appropriate forms of assistance in the longer term by the UNCT.

tag.narrative: 16.3 - Främja rättssäkerheten på nationell och internationell nivå samt säkerställa lika tillgång till rättvisa för alla.
16.3 - Promote the rule of law at the national and international levels and ensure equal access to justice for all.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

title.narrative: Rule of law joint programme decision on agreement amendment
Rule of law joint programme decision on contribution

description.narrative: Reported results in 2018 and 2019 include: Outcome 1: Capacity of justice and security institutions strengthened and linkages forged • Result 1.1: In-depth capacity assessment of the Liberian legislature completed• Result 1.2: Development of new five-year strategic plan (2019-2023) for the judiciary initiated• Result 1.3: Deployment of 60 additional Magisterial Court level judges supported • Result 1.4: Coordination and oversight role of the Ministry of Justice enhanced through continued support to the Planning and Programme Management Unit• Result 1.5: Implementation of the National Human Rights Action Plan of Liberia supported• Result 1.6: Compliance with human rights treaty reporting obligations improved• Result 1.7: Grassroots approaches to safety and security supported, notably by reinforcing the role of the security councils at county and district level• Result 1.8: Regulatory framework put in place for both the Liberia National Police and the Liberia Immigration Service• Result 1.9: Capacity of the LNP Finance Division enhanced by embedding a finance expert • Result 1.10: Implementation of the LNP’s community policing policy supported• Result 1.11: Establishment of a proper plea bargaining system supported• Result 1.12: Deployment of six additional prosecutors, two additional case liaison officers and two additional victim support officers supported • Result 1.13: Investigation and prosecution capacity of the specialised Women and Children Protection Section and the SGBV Crimes Prosecution Unit enhanced• Result 1.14: 153 duty uniforms for LNP personnel purchased and distributed across five counties• Result 1.15: Renovation and refurbishment of border crossings in Garley Town (Grand Gedeh) and Nyeken (River Gee) completed• Result 1.16: 45 motorbikes purchased and handed over to LIS• Result 1.17: Recruitment, training and deployment of 25 additional probation officers supported • Result 1.18: Investigative capacity of the Bureau of Corrections and Rehabilitation enhanced• Result 1.19: Construction of new correctional facility in Robertsport (Grand Cape Mount) completed• Result 1.20: Deployment of nine additional human rights monitors supported • Result 1.21: Capacity assessment of the Independent National Commission on Human Rights undertaken in conjunction with NANHRI• Result 1.22: Confidence- and trust-building between the different justice and security institutions promoted Outcome 2: Civil society contribution to rule of law and community access to justice enhanced• Result 2.1: Partnership agreements put in place with 16 CSOs/CBOs • Result 2.2: Civil society capacity to provide tailored legal aid and assistance enhanced• Result 2.3: Tailored legal aid services provided to 1,243 people, including 744 women and girls• Result 2.4: Legal awareness-raising activities undertaken across 14 counties, reaching a total of 46,776 people• Result 2.5: 684 monitoring visits to local courts and police stations undertaken• Result 2.6: 347 informal justice actors trained on national and international human rights norms and standards• Result 2.7: 599 conflicts and disputes mediated outside the formal justice system, including through a number of community mediation teams• Result 2.8: Linkages between selected CSOs/CBOs and the Independent National Commission on Human Rights strengthened Outcome 3: Gender responsiveness of justice, security and legislative actors strengthened and women and girls’ access to justice and security improved• Result 3.1: Investigation and prosecution capacity of the Women and Children Protection Section and the SGBV Crimes Prosecution Unit enhanced• Result 3.2: Establishment of additional divisions of Court E in Bong and and Nimba supported• Result 3.3: Tailored legal aid services provided to 320 victims/survivors of SGBV• Result 3.4: 299 women and girls assisted to realise their rights under Liberia’s personal status lawsOutcome 4: Capacity of key actors and stakeholders to monitor progress and results in rule of law development supported• Result 4.1: Public expenditure review of the Liberian justice and security sectors undertaken• Result 4.2: Public perception survey to establish the extent to which Liberians engage with and trust the different justice and security institutions completed In 2019, many of the above activities continued. Examples of achieved results in 2019 relating to continued activities include: Support to Criminal Court E, a specialised court for SGBV crimes. enabled the court to function more efficiently. During the period under review, 252 cases were assigned to Criminal Court E, in Monrovia and 172 convictions were secured. Through the programme, Court E was also established in Bong and Nimba and judges were assigned. The Programme procured and delivered two vehicles and six motorbikes to the Judiciary to enhance mobility and transportation needs of the judges and public defenders. This intervention has critically increased access to justice and legal representation with 84 cases being defended by public defenders benefiting 116 persons during the period under review. The Programme provided legal aid services to 670 pre-trial detainees, including 84 women at the police and prisons, resulting in a 3% reduction in arbitrary pre-trial detention. In addition, 1,723 persons benefitted from legal aid services provided by CSOs. Further, 838 monitoring visits were conducted to assess the performance of justice and security institutions.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 I FN:s Säkerhetsrådsresolution 2239 från 2015, bekräftades att FN:s fredsbevarande mission i Liberia (UNMIL) som funnits på plats i landet sedan 2003, ska dras tillbaka den 30 september i år. Neddragningen har skett gradvis under de senaste åren och innebär en successiv överlämning av ansvar till den liberianska regeringen (GoL) för säkerheten i landet och skydd av civilbefolkningen. Liberias regering återtog, som resolutionen påbjöd, fullt ansvar för säkerheten i landet den 30 juni i år, men allvarliga resurs- och kapacitetsbrister föreligger. I resolutionen skriver Säkerhetsrådet att Liberias regering bör arbeta fram en plan med tidslinjer och indikatorer för säkerhetssektorreform innehållande planer för ledarskap, koordinering, uppföljning och resurser, översynsmekanismer etcetera. Resolutionen understryker vikten av att GoL genomför reform av säkerhets- respektive rättssektorn.
GoL tog fram Government of Liberia Plan for UNMIL Transition med en narrativ text kring utmaningar och prioriteringar samt en matris med mål och aktiviteter. Transitionsplanen är gravt underfinansierad och understryker behovet av stöd från internationella givare till transitionsplanen och säkerhetssektorn i stort.
Svag kapacitet hos implementerande parter och korruption i säkerhets- och rättsinstitutionerna medför en relativt hög risknivå som fordrar noggrann uppföljning. Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen är ett stöd för implementering av Forums Syds projekt: ”Sustainable ownership: empowering communities and civil society Liberia”. Projektet har som mål att bygga upp det liberianska civilsamhällets kapacitet genom att stärka och öka närvaron av lokala civilsamhällesorganisationer på den liberianska landsbygden. Civilsamhället avser att öka kapaciteten för rättighetsbärare, som lever under marginaliserade förhållanden, att ha anspråk på sina rättigheter och specifikt rättigheterna att delta i lokala initiativ och utvecklingsprocesser. Projektet kommer nå ut till 26 lokala organisationer (14 som mottagare av bidrag och 12 som motagare av igångsättningsstöd ”seed grants”) i 7 av Liberias 15 counties (län). Projektet har en treårig implementeringscykel från mitten av 2018 till mitten av 2021.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The contribution is a support to Forum Syd for the implementation of the project Sustainable ownership: empwering communities and civil society in Liberia. The project has an objective to build capacity of civil society organizations in Liberia to strengthen local CSOs presence in rural counties in Liberia through increased capacity of rights-holders living under marginalised conditions to claim their rights and participate in locally owned initiatives and local development processes. The project will reach 26 local organizations (14 as receipients of sub-grants and 12 as receipients of seed grants) in seven of Liberia's 15 counties. The project has three years implementation cycle mid 2018-2021. A simplified environment assessment was done by Forum Syd, in additional an environment and climate review by Sida Helpdesk on environment and climate made recommendations that will informed continuous environment improvement in the project. Resources in budget and project work plan for environment and climate has been made. For gender, resources in the budget and plan has been allocated to integrate the gender perspective and Forum Syd has described in their theory of change an attention to mainstream gender. For this reason both environment and climate and gender marker are significant for the project.

The main objective of the proposed intervention is 'Civil society organizations have developed and strengthened their presence in rural counties in Liberia through increased capacity of rights-holders living under marginalized conditions to claim their rights and participate in locally owned initiatives and local development processes.' Three main outcomes are expected to be achieved by the project: 1. Partner organizations and communities have developed their capacities to participate in decision-making processes; 2. Partner organizations have developed their advocacy and monitoring skills of government institutions, public service providers and/or private sector actors' performance in relations to the three thematic areas of the programme; 3. Partner organizations and existing CSO networks have the capacity and resources to develop, fund-raise and implement projects of their own choice that are clearly linked to the needs and priorities identified by involved rights-holder groups and communities. The proposed intervention will reach a total of 26 local CSOs in rural Liberia in two categories - 14 local CSOs as sub-grants and 12 grassroots organizations will receive seed grants. The overall focus of the project is civil society strengthening within three areas: governance and accountability, gender equality and environment and climate change resilience and sustainable use of natural resources. All partners are expected to actively promote gender equality, and some of the organizations will focus on improving environment through sustainable agriculture methods, sustainable energy alternatives, awareness raising on environment and climate change. All partner organizations are expected to mainstream their work through an environment lens, using environmentally sustainable working methods and increase their awareness and knowledge on environment and climate change, natural resource management and rights. The overall goal of the project is to respond to the limited rights and opportunities in rural communities, and the limited presence of participatory and locally based development initiatives. In addition to support to already existing CSOs in the rural areas, the proposed intervention will support non-registered right-holders strengthen their organizations. This is important and relevant for small scale local initiatives that face disadvantage due to high registration cost and lengthy bureaucratic processes that deny them formal registration. Where formal registration is used as criteria to receive donor assistance, rural based organizations representing people living in poverty are often left out. Forum Syd's expressed commitment to reach non-registered right-holders to strengthen their organizations is addressing this important gap. Forum Syd in its proposed intervention intends to achieve its goal to strengthen the capacity of CSOs in rural Liberia through four key methods: a) Build capacities of local CSOs to develop their own sustainability plans and project ideas, as well as to deepen their discussions on their mission and vision, and engage in long-term strategic planning; implement and monitor participatory and inclusive local sustainable development initiatives; be better equipped to raise awareness and mobilize rights-holders through a human rights-based approach and support rights-holders to organize themselves and engage in collective action. b) Strengthen a rights-based and gender aware development of local CSO, supporting increased internal accountability, transparency and member-based decision-making processes; c) Build capacity of local authorities/duty bearers, service providers, community structures and traditional authorities, in their understanding of their duties and obligations, the role of civil society, and how to engage in transparent, accountable, participatory, inclusive, gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable processes with rights-holders and communities d) Promote dialogue and inclusive democratic decision-making processes involving rights-holders, local CSOs and government institutions at the county and national level. The partner organizations to be supported by Forum Syd at the end of the project will demonstrate a number of positive change in attitudes, behaviors and relations: they will be better organized for collective actions on issues relating to gender, environment and and climate change and sustainable use of natural resources; they will have better understanding of the role, obligations and responsibilities of the key duty bearers of the State and will possess better skills to advocate, negotiate and undertake joint activities with duty bearers at the local and national levels. Communities in the seven counties of the project (Bomi, Bong, Grand Gedeh, Nimba, Montserrado, Grand Bassa and Grand Cape Mount) are expected to experience increase activities of Forum Syd supported partners in the areas of gender equality, environment and climate change and sustainable use of natural resources.

tag.narrative: 16.6 - Bygga upp effektiva och transparenta institutioner med ansvarsutkrävande på alla nivåer.
16.6 - Develop effective, accountable and transparent institutions at all levels.
5.1 - Avskaffa alla former av diskriminering av alla kvinnor och flickor överallt
5.1 - End all forms of discrimination against all women and girls everywhere.

title.narrative: Forum Syd civil society strengthening agreement
Forum Syd civil society strengthening decision on contribution

description.narrative: Specific progress on the three outcomes/result areas are documented below:Outcome 1 (organizations’ capacity to participate in decision-making processes): Forum Syd approved 11 grants to CSOs in 2019 with the aim to strengthen their capacity as organizations and increase their knowledge in thematic areas and the roles of duty bearers and rights holders. Forum Syd also prepared nine new grants for approval by the grant making committee and supported two community events that contributed to Outcome 1: a celebration of activism and an awareness raising event focused on the rights of girls. Outcome 2 (monitoring and advocacy skills): took the form of, for example, women’s leadership empowerment and engaging duty-bearers in dialog on farming and climate change. Under the Land Rights Component, Forum Syd analyzed a mapping Report; devised the grant application focusing on Land Rights; and trained staff and local CSOs in the Forum Syd Right(s) Way Forward (RWF) methodology. Outcome 3 (builds on Outcomes 1 and 2): This is expected to show specific results at a later date but the ground work continues: grant making to CSOs; the land rights component is defined and partners identified and systems, procedures, trained staff and partners are in place.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Insatsen är ett stöd för implementering av Forums Syds projekt: ”Sustainable ownership: empowering communities and civil society Liberia”. Projektet har som mål att bygga upp det liberianska civilsamhällets kapacitet genom att stärka och öka närvaron av lokala civilsamhällesorganisationer på den liberianska landsbygden. Civilsamhället avser att öka kapaciteten för rättighetsbärare, som lever under marginaliserade förhållanden, att ha anspråk på sina rättigheter och specifikt rättigheterna att delta i lokala initiativ och utvecklingsprocesser. Projektet kommer nå ut till 26 lokala organisationer (14 som mottagare av bidrag och 12 som motagare av igångsättningsstöd ”seed grants”) i 7 av Liberias 15 counties (län). Projektet har en treårig implementeringscykel från mitten av 2018 till mitten av 2021.

Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 The contribution is a support to Forum Syd for the implementation of the project Sustainable ownership: empwering communities and civil society in Liberia. The project has an objective to build capacity of civil society organizations in Liberia to strengthen local CSOs presence in rural counties in Liberia through increased capacity of rights-holders living under marginalised conditions to claim their rights and participate in locally owned initiatives and local development processes. The project will reach 26 local organizations (14 as receipients of sub-grants and 12 as receipients of seed grants) in seven of Liberia's 15 counties. The project has three years implementation cycle mid 2018-2021. A simplified environment assessment was done by Forum Syd, in additional an environment and climate review by Sida Helpdesk on environment and climate made recommendations that will informed continuous environment improvement in the project. Resources in budget and project work plan for environment and climate has been made. For gender, resources in the budget and plan has been allocated to integrate the gender perspective and Forum Syd has described in their theory of change an attention to mainstream gender. For this reason both environment and climate and gender marker are significant for the project.

The main objective of the proposed intervention is 'Civil society organizations have developed and strengthened their presence in rural counties in Liberia through increased capacity of rights-holders living under marginalized conditions to claim their rights and participate in locally owned initiatives and local development processes.' Three main outcomes are expected to be achieved by the project: 1. Partner organizations and communities have developed their capacities to participate in decision-making processes; 2. Partner organizations have developed their advocacy and monitoring skills of government institutions, public service providers and/or private sector actors' performance in relations to the three thematic areas of the programme; 3. Partner organizations and existing CSO networks have the capacity and resources to develop, fund-raise and implement projects of their own choice that are clearly linked to the needs and priorities identified by involved rights-holder groups and communities. The proposed intervention will reach a total of 26 local CSOs in rural Liberia in two categories - 14 local CSOs as sub-grants and 12 grassroots organizations will receive seed grants. The overall focus of the project is civil society strengthening within three areas: governance and accountability, gender equality and environment and climate change resilience and sustainable use of natural resources. All partners are expected to actively promote gender equality, and some of the organizations will focus on improving environment through sustainable agriculture methods, sustainable energy alternatives, awareness raising on environment and climate change. All partner organizations are expected to mainstream their work through an environment lens, using environmentally sustainable working methods and increase their awareness and knowledge on environment and climate change, natural resource management and rights. The overall goal of the project is to respond to the limited rights and opportunities in rural communities, and the limited presence of participatory and locally based development initiatives. In addition to support to already existing CSOs in the rural areas, the proposed intervention will support non-registered right-holders strengthen their organizations. This is important and relevant for small scale local initiatives that face disadvantage due to high registration cost and lengthy bureaucratic processes that deny them formal registration. Where formal registration is used as criteria to receive donor assistance, rural based organizations representing people living in poverty are often left out. Forum Syd's expressed commitment to reach non-registered right-holders to strengthen their organizations is addressing this important gap. Forum Syd in its proposed intervention intends to achieve its goal to strengthen the capacity of CSOs in rural Liberia through four key methods: a) Build capacities of local CSOs to develop their own sustainability plans and project ideas, as well as to deepen their discussions on their mission and vision, and engage in long-term strategic planning; implement and monitor participatory and inclusive local sustainable development initiatives; be better equipped to raise awareness and mobilize rights-holders through a human rights-based approach and support rights-holders to organize themselves and engage in collective action. b) Strengthen a rights-based and gender aware development of local CSO, supporting increased internal accountability, transparency and member-based decision-making processes; c) Build capacity of local authorities/duty bearers, service providers, community structures and traditional authorities, in their understanding of their duties and obligations, the role of civil society, and how to engage in transparent, accountable, participatory, inclusive, gender sensitive and environmentally sustainable processes with rights-holders and communities d) Promote dialogue and inclusive democratic decision-making processes involving rights-holders, local CSOs and government institutions at the county and national level. The partner organizations to be supported by Forum Syd at the end of the project will demonstrate a number of positive change in attitudes, behaviors and relations: they will be better organized for collective actions on issues relating to gender, environment and and climate change and sustainable use of natural resources; they will have better understanding of the role, obligations and responsibilities of the key duty bearers of the State and will possess better skills to advocate, negotiate and undertake joint activities with duty bearers at the local and national levels. Communities in the seven counties of the project (Bomi, Bong, Grand Gedeh, Nimba, Montserrado, Grand Bassa and Grand Cape Mount) are expected to experience increase activities of Forum Syd supported partners in the areas of gender equality, environment and climate change and sustainable use of natural resources.

tag.narrative: 5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

title.narrative: COVID-19 DIAKONIA - Strengthening Civil Society Organisations in the DRC 2018 - 2021
COVID-19 DIAKONIA - Strengthening Civil Society Organisations in the DRC 2018 - 2021

description.narrative:
Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Nya medel/medeltillägg för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 Diakonia har sökt biståndsmedel från Sida om 42 877 799 SEK för programmet "Ett starkare civilt samhälle för ett värdigt liv" för perioden juni 2018 - maj 2021.
Insatsens övergripande mål är demokratisk en samhällsbyggnad där alla kvinnor, män, flickor och pojkar ska kunna leva i frihet, kräva sina rättigheter och åtnjuta ett liv i fred och värdighet.
Insatsen syftar till att: a. stärka civilsamhället och demokratin samt förespråka ansvarighet, jämställdhet och större respekt för mänskliga rättigheter; b. stärka rösten för kongolesiska medborgare, särskilt kvinnor, när det kommer till utkrävandet av mänskliga rättigheter; c. fler kvinnor ska vara delaktiga i offentliga beslutsfattanden samt att främja lagar och policys som inte är diskriminerande mot kvinnor; d. kongolesiska medborgare använder demokratin, väljer sina lokala, regionala och nationella ledare samt utkräver ansvar ifrån dessa ledare.
Diakonia kommer att genomföra programmet tillsammans med åtta organisationer för det lokala civilsamhället i DR Kongo. Diakonia avser även att ingå avtal med ytterligare partners vad avser kulturella aktiviteter inom programmet. Innan beslut fattas om dessa ska Diakonia först konsultera Sida.
Totalt kommer Diakonia vidareförmedla 56% av budgeten till åtta lokala organisationer. Insatsen kommer huvudsakligen att genomföras i Kongo Central, Kwilu, Maindombe, Kasai Central, Lualaba och Kinshasa.

The programme describes how Diakonia intends to strengthen Congolese civil society organization and administrative as well self-management capacity in the DRC. It also describes objectives and proposed results, mainly focused on the better understanding of the democratic process, motoring of human rights violation, capacity of women and youth leaders to engage with public institutions for life indignity as well youth pro-democracy to engage in democratic debate and to improve DRC transparency and accountability, especially during the State management.

tag.narrative: 3.4 - By 2030, reduce by one third premature mortality from non-communicable diseases through prevention and treatment and promote mental health and well-being.
3.4 - Till 2030 genom förebyggande insatser och behandling minska det antal människor som dör i förtid av icke smittsamma sjukdomar med en tredjedel samt främja psykisk hälsa och välbefinnande.

title.narrative: Diakonia-Strengthening Civil Society Organisations in the DRC 2018-2021

description.narrative: Between 15th June 2019 - May 14th 2020, Diakonia continued to implement “Strengthening Civil Society Organisations in the DRC 2018 – 2021” as planned in year 2. But, when the Covid19 pandemic broke out, the DRC Government applied measures that obliged partners to adjust programmes after consultation with the Embassy. The main achievements were in capacity building of all 8 partner organizations: Administrative and Financial Management; Two curricula for Women, Youth, PLWD Human Resources and Civic Education were designed; sensitization campaigns and monitoring of Human Rights was documented; Establishment of Multi-Actor Dialogue Framework and Women & Girls training in Feminine held in all selected provinces; Transformational Leadership and Gender Justice capacity building and production of Training Module on Gender, Women’s Rights; Advocacy by the Demo/HR consortium upon local Electoral training of youth electoral Observation and meaningful vote and participative democracy. Result areas and outcomes during the period include: Outcome 1: Civil society strengthened in order to advocate for democracy, accountability, gender equality and greater respect for Human Rights, in dialogue with duty bearers 33 Dialogue frames established in the 6 provinces (members are now doing joint advocacy activities; The Framework is now considered as the official voice of the CS towards the authorities. They are now asking the frame to provide their input for authorities’ planning) 3 Consortia established (2 are functional: Human Rights defenders and Democracy) by ACAJ, VSV, CEHAJ1325 for HR chaired by ACAJ; by NSCC, LYREC and CEJP for Democracy chaired by NSCC. Staffs from all 8 partner organisations have had their financial management capacity reinforced, resulting in their financial management practices, as shown by the audit report which showed drastic improvements. Outcome 2: The Congolese citizens, in particular women and youth, demand respect for Human Rights Human Rights Module (being prepared by CEHAJ1325 Specialists): To be integrated into the Basic Education Curriculum. A Civic Education Module on Human Rights (under preparation, by ACAJ Specialists) Human Rights sensitisation campaigns in the 6 provinces (by ACAJ, VSV, LYREC & CEHAJ1325) Workshop on Human Rights Violation Monitoring (Kongo Central, by ACAJ) Monitoring of Human Rights Violation (VSV) Study on Human Rights practices within security services (Ongoing, by CEHAJ1325) Protection of HRD in danger (by HR Protection Mechanism set by Diakonia within the HR Consortium) Outcome 3: Increased number of women present in public decision-making processes promoting non-discriminatory laws and public policies towards women Electoral reforms Advocacy (by Diakonia partners and non partners, led by NSCC; result: preparation of & dissemination of CS-wide Vade-Mecum); initiatives to reinforce DRC Women’s political participation (led by FMJC; resulting in an Advocacy Strategy) Girls’ participation in decision-making organs at the local level: This to be revealed by the evaluation report. Preparation of a training module on gender and Women’s Rights (by CONAFED, distributed to Gender & Development Local Committees). Outcome 4: Congolese citizens embrace democracy, elect their provincial and national leaders, and hold them to account Deployment of community mobilisers and dissemination of sensitization materials/cards on decentralization and local elections: Diakonia noticed an improvement in the understanding of their role by the population as rights-holders in terms of democracy and elections (consciousness). Compilation and validation of Multi-Stakeholder Dialogue Frameworks’ priority list (these have been sent to Provincial Governments for consideration in their planning cycles). Awareness-raising Campaign on ‘Meaningful’ Voting and Participatory Democracy. (Impact: The Catholic Church confirmed that the population voted according to manifesto, not personalities). Training of Election Observers (Impact: EU, Carter Centre, AU Observation missions all uploaded the vital and important role played by Congolese Electoral Observers. This is expected to continue for local elections, still to be held).
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNICEF - Stöd till landprogram i DRK 2018-2021
COVID-19 UNICEF - Support to Unicef country program in DRC 2018-2021

description.narrative:
New/additional funds to address COVID-19 UNICEF has submitted an application for support to its country program. This contribution is a consolidated support to the implementation of UNICEF country program in DRC, focusing on three thematic areas: health, protection of children who previously were involved with in armed groups and strengthening vulnerable societies’ capacity to withstand recurrent crises (resilience).
The contribution is in line with the priorities of Sweden's Development Cooperation Strategy with DRC 2021-2025- specifically areas 2: Equitable health and nutrition, result area 3: Inclusive and sustainable communities as well as our cross-cutting focus resilience/nexus by strengthening the resilience of vulnerable groups and societies.
This support will specifically contribute to improved access to high-quality care for children and pregnant women. Explicitly, the contribution’s results concern improved vaccination coverage, access to basic drugs to treat diarrhea, pneumonia and malaria at community levels, water and sanitation, and the strengthening of health systems for sustainability of the results. Attention to young women and adolescents' SRHR needs (including menstrual hygiene) is emphasized more than ever, in line with UNICEF Gender Action Plan (GAP) 2018-2021.
Children released from armed groups will have access to psychosocial assistance and be given support to reintegrate their communities, resume their education or engage in economic activities. The contribution will also help strengthen resilience or reduce vulnerability (health / nutrition, education, conflict transformation / reconciliation, water and sanitation, etc.) among internally displaced persons and local populations so that they can better prevent or cope with further crises in the future.
UNICEF's country program in DRC covered initially the period 2013-2017, it was then extended until 2019. The current program covers the period 2020-2024, and is based on UNICEF's global Strategic Plan 2018-2021 adopted by UNICEF's Board in 2017. The priority areas of the UNICEF country program are health, protection of vulnerable children (protection), education and humanitarian assistance and resilience.
Sida previously supported UNICEF DRC through three different contributions: one thematic support for health, one project's support for child protection and another for resilience. This contribution is a consolidated model and has gradually gathered all Swedish support to UNICEF DRC country program. This modality aims to increase both ??flexibility (easier planning and reinforcing synergies between interventions in the focus areas on the partner's side), but also cost-effectiveness by enabling better utilization of resources (including reduced administrative staff time and cost, joint follow-up and dialogue meetings, etc.) for both UNICEF and the Embassy. In 2018, this support was directed to health, whereas in 2019 both health and protection of children associated with armed conflict will be supported. From 2020 the Embassy had only one comprehensive contribution to UNICEF country programme in DRC through all three focus areas (health, child protection and resilience).

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 United Nations Childrens Fund (Unicef) har vänt sig till Sida och ansökt om stöd till implementering av landprogrammet. Stödet är tematiskt och omfattar hälsa, skydd för barn som kommit i kontakt med väpnade grupper samt förstärkning av utsatta samhällens kapacitet att stå emot återkommande kriser.
Insatsen motsvarar Sveriges prioriteringar i den nuvarande strategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med DRK 2021-2025, särskilt avseende områdena förbättrad grundläggande hälsa och värnad mänsklig säkerhet och frihet från våld.
Insatsen förväntas bidra till en förbättrad lokal tillgång till en högkvalitativ vård för barn och gravida kvinnor, särskilt avseende tillgång till vaccination och basläkemedel för diarréer, lunginflammation och malaria. Dessutom åsyftas en förbättrad tillgång till lokala vatten- och sanitetssystem samt även till ett allmänt förstärkt hälsosystem. I linje med Unicefs aktionsplan för genderfrågor (Gender Action Plan, 2018-2021) betonas särskilt unga kvinnors och ungdomars behov av stöd avseende sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR).
Vidare avser insatsen att ge de barn som deltagit i beväpnade grupper tillgång till psykosocialt stöd. Dessutom omfattas stöd till barnens integrering i deras ursprungliga samhällen samt återupptagande av skolgång eller egen försörjning genom ekonomiska aktiviteter. Insatsen avser även bidra till att förstärka och minska sårbarheten hos internflyktingar och lokalbefolkning genom bl.a. förbättrad hälsa, nutrition, utbildning samt vatten- och sanitet så att de lättare klarar av framtida kriser.
Unicefs landprogram i DRK nuvarande landprogram gäller för perioden 2020-2024. Programmet bygger vidare på Unicefs globala verksamhetsplan (2018-2021) som antogs av Unicefs styrelse år 2017.
Sida har tidigare lämnat stöd till Unicef i DRK genom tre olika insatser: ett tematiskt stöd till hälsa, ett projektsstöd till barnsskydd och ett projektsstöd till resiliens. Denna instats lägger ihop dessa tidigare projektstöd. Det samlade stödet innebär ökad flexibilitet och effektivitet i planering och implentering, bl.a. på grund av tydligare synergier mellan de berörda fokusområdena. Stödet bedöms även leda till en effektivare resursanvändning av personal samt ett effektivare samarbete mellan Unicef och ambassaden.

This contribution is aimed at supporting the implementation of UNICEF Country Programme in DRC 2018-2021, namely the achievement of the following goal areas: 1) every child survives and thrives, 2) every child is protected from violence and 3) every child lives in a safe and clean environment. In health, the objective of the intervention is specifically to increase the coverage of high impact interventions on maternal, adolescent and child health in the countries' health zones and to encourage the adoption of responsible behaviours by adolescents and young people to prevent unwanted pregnancies, HIV/AIDS and human papilloma virus (HPV) as well as to support positive health policy development centrally and at intermediate levels in the country. It is expected that in four years time, three quarters of the 516 Health Zones in DRC will be able to provide the high impact interventions on maternal, adolescent and child health, and at least 80% of targeted villages are certified as child-friendly communities. With regard to protection, this intervention will contribute to promote governance for child protection and strengthening protective environment from all forms of violence in the country. In terms of results, the support will contribute to identification, interim care and psychosocial support, reunification and reintegration measures and quality services for at least 50% of the affected children; as well as to operationalization of surveillance mechanisms (i.e. the "Monitoring and Reporting Mechanism on Grave Child Violations of children's rights in armed conflicts (MRM) 1612" and the "Monitoring, Analysis, and Reporting Arrangements on Conflict-Related Sexual Violence (MARA) 1888") in order to improve prevention of and response to grave violations of children’s rights. The interventions in transitional zones is aimed at improving coverage of basic social services and in strengthening communities' capacity to manage key risks and vulnerabilities. Results in terms of increased access to basic social services concern access to primary education, to health services including prevention and treatment of severe malnutrition, to safe water and sanitation. Strengthening community-level social protection neworks, including using cash transfer mechanisms. The contribution is very much in line with the priorities outlined in the Swedish Development Cooperation Strategy with DRC 2015-2019 - specifically with respect to the objectives related to "Improving Basic Health and to "Protected Human Security and Freedom From Violence", including by strengthening the resilience of vulnerable groups and societies.

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

This contribution is aimed at supporting the implementation of UNICEF Country Programme in DRC 2018-2021, namely the achievement of the following goal areas: 1) every child survives and thrives, 2) every child is protected from violence and 3) every child lives in a safe and clean environment. In health, the objective of the intervention is specifically to increase the coverage of high impact interventions on maternal, adolescent and child health in the countries' health zones and to encourage the adoption of responsible behaviours by adolescents and young people to prevent unwanted pregnancies, HIV/AIDS and human papilloma virus (HPV) as well as to support positive health policy development centrally and at intermediate levels in the country. It is expected that in four years time, three quarters of the 516 Health Zones in DRC will be able to provide the high impact interventions on maternal, adolescent and child health, and at least 80% of targeted villages are certified as child-friendly communities. With regard to protection, this intervention will contribute to promote governance for child protection and strengthening protective environment from all forms of violence in the country. In terms of results, the support will contribute to identification, interim care and psychosocial support, reunification and reintegration measures and quality services for at least 50% of the affected children; as well as to operationalization of surveillance mechanisms (i.e. the "Monitoring and Reporting Mechanism on Grave Child Violations of children's rights in armed conflicts (MRM) 1612" and the "Monitoring, Analysis, and Reporting Arrangements on Conflict-Related Sexual Violence (MARA) 1888") in order to improve prevention of and response to grave violations of children’s rights. The interventions in transitional zones is aimed at improving coverage of basic social services and in strengthening communities' capacity to manage key risks and vulnerabilities. Results in terms of increased access to basic social services concern access to primary education, to health services including prevention and treatment of severe malnutrition, to safe water and sanitation. Strengthening community-level social protection neworks, including using cash transfer mechanisms. The contribution is very much in line with the priorities outlined in the Swedish Development Cooperation Strategy with DRC 2015-2019 - specifically with respect to the objectives related to "Improving Basic Health and to "Protected Human Security and Freedom From Violence", including by strengthening the resilience of vulnerable groups and societies.

tag.narrative: 16.2 - Eliminera övergrepp, utnyttjande, människohandel och alla former av våld eller tortyr mot barn.
16.2 - End abuse, exploitation, trafficking and all forms of violence against and torture of children.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

title.narrative: COVID-19 UNICEF - Stöd till landprogram i DRK 2018-2021
COVID-19 UNICEF - Support to Unicef country program in DRC 2018-2021

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 United Nations Childrens Fund (Unicef) har vänt sig till Sida och ansökt om stöd till implementering av landprogrammet. Stödet är tematiskt och omfattar hälsa, skydd för barn som kommit i kontakt med väpnade grupper samt förstärkning av utsatta samhällens kapacitet att stå emot återkommande kriser.
Insatsen motsvarar Sveriges prioriteringar i den nuvarande strategin för utvecklingssamarbetet med DRK 2021-2025, särskilt avseende områdena förbättrad grundläggande hälsa och värnad mänsklig säkerhet och frihet från våld.
Insatsen förväntas bidra till en förbättrad lokal tillgång till en högkvalitativ vård för barn och gravida kvinnor, särskilt avseende tillgång till vaccination och basläkemedel för diarréer, lunginflammation och malaria. Dessutom åsyftas en förbättrad tillgång till lokala vatten- och sanitetssystem samt även till ett allmänt förstärkt hälsosystem. I linje med Unicefs aktionsplan för genderfrågor (Gender Action Plan, 2018-2021) betonas särskilt unga kvinnors och ungdomars behov av stöd avseende sexuell och reproduktiv hälsa och rättigheter (SRHR).
Vidare avser insatsen att ge de barn som deltagit i beväpnade grupper tillgång till psykosocialt stöd. Dessutom omfattas stöd till barnens integrering i deras ursprungliga samhällen samt återupptagande av skolgång eller egen försörjning genom ekonomiska aktiviteter. Insatsen avser även bidra till att förstärka och minska sårbarheten hos internflyktingar och lokalbefolkning genom bl.a. förbättrad hälsa, nutrition, utbildning samt vatten- och sanitet så att de lättare klarar av framtida kriser.
Unicefs landprogram i DRK nuvarande landprogram gäller för perioden 2020-2024. Programmet bygger vidare på Unicefs globala verksamhetsplan (2018-2021) som antogs av Unicefs styrelse år 2017.
Sida har tidigare lämnat stöd till Unicef i DRK genom tre olika insatser: ett tematiskt stöd till hälsa, ett projektsstöd till barnsskydd och ett projektsstöd till resiliens. Denna instats lägger ihop dessa tidigare projektstöd. Det samlade stödet innebär ökad flexibilitet och effektivitet i planering och implentering, bl.a. på grund av tydligare synergier mellan de berörda fokusområdena. Stödet bedöms även leda till en effektivare resursanvändning av personal samt ett effektivare samarbete mellan Unicef och ambassaden.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 UNICEF has submitted an application for support to its country program. This contribution is a consolidated support to the implementation of UNICEF country program in DRC, focusing on three thematic areas: health, protection of children who previously were involved with in armed groups and strengthening vulnerable societies’ capacity to withstand recurrent crises (resilience).
The contribution is in line with the priorities of Sweden's Development Cooperation Strategy with DRC 2021-2025- specifically areas 2: Equitable health and nutrition, result area 3: Inclusive and sustainable communities as well as our cross-cutting focus resilience/nexus by strengthening the resilience of vulnerable groups and societies.
This support will specifically contribute to improved access to high-quality care for children and pregnant women. Explicitly, the contribution’s results concern improved vaccination coverage, access to basic drugs to treat diarrhea, pneumonia and malaria at community levels, water and sanitation, and the strengthening of health systems for sustainability of the results. Attention to young women and adolescents' SRHR needs (including menstrual hygiene) is emphasized more than ever, in line with UNICEF Gender Action Plan (GAP) 2018-2021.
Children released from armed groups will have access to psychosocial assistance and be given support to reintegrate their communities, resume their education or engage in economic activities. The contribution will also help strengthen resilience or reduce vulnerability (health / nutrition, education, conflict transformation / reconciliation, water and sanitation, etc.) among internally displaced persons and local populations so that they can better prevent or cope with further crises in the future.
UNICEF's country program in DRC covered initially the period 2013-2017, it was then extended until 2019. The current program covers the period 2020-2024, and is based on UNICEF's global Strategic Plan 2018-2021 adopted by UNICEF's Board in 2017. The priority areas of the UNICEF country program are health, protection of vulnerable children (protection), education and humanitarian assistance and resilience.
Sida previously supported UNICEF DRC through three different contributions: one thematic support for health, one project's support for child protection and another for resilience. This contribution is a consolidated model and has gradually gathered all Swedish support to UNICEF DRC country program. This modality aims to increase both ??flexibility (easier planning and reinforcing synergies between interventions in the focus areas on the partner's side), but also cost-effectiveness by enabling better utilization of resources (including reduced administrative staff time and cost, joint follow-up and dialogue meetings, etc.) for both UNICEF and the Embassy. In 2018, this support was directed to health, whereas in 2019 both health and protection of children associated with armed conflict will be supported. From 2020 the Embassy had only one comprehensive contribution to UNICEF country programme in DRC through all three focus areas (health, child protection and resilience).

tag.narrative: 2.2 - By 2030, end all forms of malnutrition, including achieving, by 2025, the internationally agreed targets on stunting and wasting in children under 5 years of age, and address the nutritional needs of adolescent girls, pregnant and lactating women and older persons.

2.2 - Senast 2030 avskaffa alla former av undernäring, bland annat genom att senast 2025 nå de internationellt överenskomna målen i fråga om tillväxthämning och undervikt bland barn under fem år, samt tillgodose tonårsflickors, gravida och ammande kvinnors samt äldre personers näringsbehov.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative: Community Health and Social Accountability Programme (CHASP) aims at increasing the utilisation of quality Reproductive, Maternal, New-born, Child Health (RMNCH) services that are accessible, acceptable, affordable and equitable through provision of essential package for health services. The programme is implemented in three different regions and a total of 10 districts of Somalia and has dual objectives: 1) to increase the utilisation of quality Reproductive, Maternal, New-born, Child Health (RMNCH) services; and 2) to develop a strong community, district and regional level referral health system. The programme primarily targets women of reproductive age and children under five years of age for health services. Besides contributing to strengthened health systems, the intervention will increase the health seeking behaviour for women and make reproductive health services accessible and affordable for the target beneficiaries. The programme will further contribute to bridging the gap between health facilities and communities.

New/additional funds to address COVID-19 Save the Children has submitted an application for program support for the years 2017-2019, with a total of 90,000,000 kronor. The contribution aims to help strengthen the Somali health sector by supporting primary health care at local level. By strengthening the capacity of local authorities in governance and decision making regarding health issues, increasing access and quality of services, and strengthening the empowerment and resilience of the population, this effort is considered to contribute to improving community health. In addition, the main focus of this contribution lies on maternity, neonatal and child health in order to help strengthen the health of women and children and their potential for survival.
Since 2012, Sida has supported the Somali health sector through a comprehensive UN Joint Program (WHO, UNICEF and UNFPA), entitled Joint Health and Nutrition Program (JHNP). UN organizations in Somalia are mainly non-implementing partners and therefore subcontract local organizations, such as Save the Children to perform and deliver services. Save the Children was the largest implementing partner organization within JHNP, which laid the foundation for the design of this new program after the JHNP ended. Sida, together with the Swiss Development Cooperation in Somalia (SDC), chose to proceed with Save the Children as an individual and direct partner, given the work previously implemented by the organization were successful. Save the Children also has access to many regions around Somalia, including hard-to-reach areas, which this contribution aims to focus on.
The choice to prepare a new support to Save the Children to strengthen the local health sector with particular attention to three regions - Galmudug, Jubbaland and Bari. The selection of regions for project implementation was guided by Save the Children, who concludes that these regions lag behind other regions in terms of access to essential health services. It is worth to remember that these regions are all previous JHNP regions and so continuation of services remains essential.
Decision on contribution will be taken by the Head of Afica Department at Sida Stockholm.

Nya medel/medeltillägg för att bekämpa covid-19 Rädda Barnen har inkommit med en ansökan för programstöd för perioden 2017-2019, med en totalt budget på 144 322 317 kronor. Sidas andel uppgår till totalt 90 000 000 kronor. Schweiz står för resterande andelen. Insatsen syftar till att dels bidra till fortsatt tillgång av basal hälso-och-sjukvårdstjänster för gravida kvinnor och barn under fem år i tre regioner i Somalia, dels fortsätta stödja uppbyggnaden av den Somaliska hälsosektorn med fokus på hälsosystem på lokal och regionalnivå. Insatsen bygger vidare på det stöd som Sverige tidigare har gett till hälsosektorn (bland annat genom Joint Health and Nutrition Program, JHNP), samtidigt som den utforskar nya aspekter inklusive implementeringsforskning för ett förbättrad resultat och kvalité. Vidare, avser instatsen att stärka kapaciteten hos de lokala auktoriteter med styrning och beslutsfattande för hälsofrågor, öka tillgången och kvalitén av hälso-och-sjukvårdstjänster samt stärka egenmakten och resiliensen hos befolkningen.
Sida har sedan 2012 stött den Somaliska hälsosektorn främst genom tre olika program inklusive ett givargemensamt FN-program (WHO, UNICEF och UNFPA), så kallad Joint Health and Nutrition Program (JHNP). Två av de enskilda program som Sida tidigare gav stöd till (Dalarna Högskola barnmorskeprogram och UNFPA pilot program för våld mot kvinnor) samt de JHNP komponenter (reproduktiv, mödra och neonatal hälsa) som UNFPA ansvarade för ingår sedan juli 2017 inom ramen för det stöd som Sida ger till UNFPA:s landprogram för år 2017. Stödet till UNFPA för perioden 2018-2020 kommer att fr.o.m. januari 2018 ingå i Sidas stöd till FN fonden (UN MPTF) för strategiska skäl (för mer information, se gärna beslut om insats med beslutsnummer 28/17). Innehållet i det program förslag som Rädda Barnen har presenterat för Sida bygger vidare på den komponent av JHNP som framför allt UNICEF ansvarade för. UNICEF implementerar inga program utan anlitar internationella och lokala organisationer, såsom Rädda Barnen för att utföra och leverera hälsotjänster. Rädda Barnen var den största implementerande partnerorganisationen inom JHNP och för UNICEF, vilket la grunden till utformandet av detta nya program, efter att JHNP avslutades. Sida, tillsammans med den Schweiziska biståndsmyndigheten (SDC), valde att gå vidare med Rädda Barnen som enskild partnersorganisation då insatserna som tidigare implementerats av organisationen var framgångsrika. Rädda Barnen har dessutom åtkomst till många regioner runtom Somalia, även svåråtkomliga områden, som denna insats avser inrikta sig på.
Sida gör därför bedömningen att planerad insats är a) i linje med resultaten för Sveriges strategi för utvecklingssamarbete, b) i linje med resultaten i Somalias nationella utvecklingsplan, samt c) bygger vidare på det stöd som Sida tidigare har gett i hälsosektorn. Denna insats bygger på principen flexibilitet och "doing development differently" och kommer att ge Sida möjligheten att bättre förstå vad som fungerar och inte i en fragil och konfliktpåverkad kontext som Somalia.
Beslut om insats tas av chef för Afrikaavdelningen på Sida Stockholm.

participating-org.narrative: Save the Children - donor country office

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.
3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: 51270022 - Decision on amendment of contribution - CHASP

description.narrative: During the third year of program implementation, CHASP continued the delivery of quality healthcare servicers combined with diverse capacity building interventions in 10 districts across Jubaland, Galmudug and Puntland. This has contributed significantly to increased access and availability of healthcare in targeted regions especially hard-to-reach areas. In the reporting period, the intervention reached 429,124 beneficiaries (178,565 males and 250,559 females), accounting for more than half of the overall health facility utilisation rate of 782,087 with quality health interventions, establishing resilient health systems and robust community structures thus laying a strong foundation for sustainability. Antenatal care results carried out during a client satisfaction interviews shows that, majority of pregnant women attended the health facilities were provided folic acid, iron tablets, tetanus toxoid injection and counseled on the importance of antenatal care and recommended diertary intake. In order to maintain adaptive programming, the intervention continued to conduct a series of research studies and client satisfaction surveys in some of the supported facilities In addition, a study to understand progress in knowledge of care givers on infant and young breast-feeding, children dietary diversity and community health status was also conducted in two districts with findings helping to modify the breast-feeding practices and nutrition programming approach. Following the dissemination of above mentioned research findings conducted, the Ministry of Health and other key health actors in the proogramme-supported regions have adapted these key findings and recommendations with the aim of improving quality health service delivery. Other results achieved in year three include: - Cost per beneficiary ratio for year 3 was maintained at 114 SEK as compared to 250 SEK in year 2;- Flexibility of the programme design maintained to adapt to changing context and learning experiences, COVID 19 and emergency funding utilized;- 77% increase in health facility utilization as compared to year 2 and more effective and efficient health leadership and coordination both at district and state level; - Rehabilitated three health facilities in Bari region. In Horseed health centre, the programme renovated the perimeter fence while in Dharjaale, the community constructed three extension rooms for delivery services; - An elevated water tank constructed for Kobdhexaad health centre improving general sanitation of the health facility, and an underground water reservoir constructed for Baargaal Referral Health centre, ensuring consistent supply of clean water at the health facility; - Stronger community involvement and ownership laying foundation for sustainability. In Galmudug, there is a slight decrease in children under five utilization for year 3 as compared to year 2. This is due to accessibility issues and migration of the population.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published

UNICEF implementerar inga program utan anlitar internationella och lokala organisationer, såsom Rädda Barnen för att utföra och leverera hälsotjänster. Rädda Barnen var den största implementerande partnerorganisationen inom JHNP och för UNICEF, vilket la grunden till utformandet av detta nya program, efter att JHNP avslutades. Sida, tillsammans med den Schweiziska biståndsmyndigheten (SDC), valde att gå vidare med Rädda Barnen som enskild partnersorganisation då insatserna som tidigare implementerats av organisationen var framgångsrika. Rädda Barnen har dessutom åtkomst till många regioner runtom Somalia, även svåråtkomliga områden, som denna insats avser inrikta sig på.
Sida gör därför bedömningen att planerad insats är a) i linje med resultaten för Sveriges strategi för utvecklingssamarbete, b) i linje med resultaten i Somalias nationella utvecklingsplan, samt c) bygger vidare på det stöd som Sida tidigare har gett i hälsosektorn. Denna insats bygger på principen flexibilitet och "doing development differently" och kommer att ge Sida möjligheten att bättre förstå vad som fungerar och inte i en fragil och konfliktpåverkad kontext som Somalia.
Beslut om insats tas av chef för Afrikaavdelningen på Sida Stockholm.

participating-org.narrative: Save the Children - donor country office

tag.narrative: 10.2 - By 2030, empower and promote the social, economic and political inclusion of all, irrespective of age, sex, disability, race, ethnicity, origin, religion or economic or other status.

10.2 - Till 2030 möjliggöra och verka för att alla människors, oavsett ålder, kön, funktionsnedsättning, ras, etnicitet, ursprung, religion eller ekonomisk eller annan ställning, blir inkluderade i det sociala, ekonomiska och politiska livet.
3.1 - By 2030, reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births.
3.1 - Till 2030 minska mödradödligheten i världen till mindre än 70 dödsfall per 100 000 förlossningar med levande barn.

3.2 - By 2030, end preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, with all countries aiming to reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births.

3.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att inga spädbarn eller barn under fem år dör av orsaker som hade kunnat förebyggas. Alla länder bör sträva efter att minska den neonatala dödligheten till högst tolv dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda och dödligheten bland barn under fem år till högst 25 dödsfall per 1 000 levande födda.

3.7 - By 2030, ensure universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including for family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programmes.

3.7 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till sexuell och reproduktiv hälsovård, inklusive familjeplanering, information och utbildning, och att reproduktiv hälsa integreras i nationella strategier och program.

3.8 - Achieve universal health coverage, including financial risk protection, access to quality essential health-care services and access to safe, effective, quality and affordable essential medicines and vaccines for all.

3.8 - Åstadkomma allmän hälso- och sjukvård för alla, som även skyddar mot ekonomisk risk, tillgång till grundläggande hälso- och sjukvård av god kvalitet liksom tillgång till säkra, effektiva och ekonomiskt överkomliga grundläggande läkemedel och vaccin av god kvalitet.
5.2 - Avskaffa alla former av våld mot alla kvinnor och flickor i det offentliga och privata rummet, inklusive människohandel, sexuellt utnyttjande och andra typer av exploatering.
5.2 - Eliminate all forms of violence against all women and girls in the public and private spheres, including trafficking and sexual and other types of exploitation.

6.2 - By 2030, achieve access to adequate and equitable sanitation and hygiene for all and end open defecation, paying special attention to the needs of women and girls and those in vulnerable situations.

6.2 - Senast 2030 säkerställa att alla har tillgång till fullgod och rättvis sanitet och hygien och att ingen behöver uträtta sina behov utomhus. Särskild uppmärksamhet bör ägnas åt behoven hos kvinnor och flickor samt människor i utsatta situationer.
